title: 103_hr467
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on the Advancement of Women in the Science and Engineering Work Forces Act". The Congress acknowledges the underrepresentation of women in science and engineering fields, higher rates of unemployment for women scientists, artificial barriers in recruitment and advancement, and the importance of diverse workforces in academia, industry, and government. The White House Task Force and Federal Coordinating Council initiatives have raised awareness about the underrepresentation of women in science and engineering fields and the need to eliminate barriers to their recruitment and advancement. Establishing a commission to address these issues would further emphasize the importance of removing these barriers. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of promoting diversity and retention of women in science and engineering fields in the United States. It aims to sensitize employers to recruit and retain women scientists and engineers to overcome projected workforce shortages in the next 20 years. Additionally, it encourages the replication of successful recruitment and retention programs by universities, corporations, and Federal agencies. Establishment of the Commission on the Advancement of Women in Science and Engineering Workforces, referred to as the "Commission." Duty of the Commission is outlined. The Commission will study the underrepresentation of women in science and engineering fields, their preparedness for advancement, employer and union policies, and barriers to their recruitment and advancement. The Commission will study the underrepresentation of women in science and engineering fields, as well as identify successful practices for their recruitment, retention, and advancement in academia, industry, and government. The Commission will issue recommendations for the recruitment, retention, and advancement of women in science and engineering. The Commission will issue recommendations for the recruitment, retention, and advancement of women in science and engineering. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders from the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Commission consists of 17 members appointed by leaders from the House of Representatives and the Senate, including the minority leader of the Senate and the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy. Initial appointments must meet specific qualifications within 180 days of the Act's enactment, considering factors like representation of women and minorities, executive positions in business, and expertise in employment issues. Additionally, political affiliation restrictions apply to members appointed from government officials. The Commission consists of 17 members appointed by leaders from the House of Representatives and the Senate, including the minority leader of the Senate and the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy. Members may continue for a 60-day period after ceasing government employment. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members receive compensation based on specified rates. Members of the Commission are entitled to compensation under section 5376 of title 5, United States Code, for their duties, including attendance at meetings and travel. Federal employees serving on the Commission cannot receive additional pay. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided in accordance with title 5. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for business transactions. The Director of the Office of Science serves as the Chairperson. The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy serves as the Chairperson of the Commission. The Commission must meet at least 5 times before completing reports and may hold additional meetings upon request. After the completion of specific reports, the Commission must meet at least once, but not more than twice. Members of the Commission are entitled to compensation and travel expenses. Members of the Commission are not considered federal employees except for specific purposes outlined in section 8(c), such as tort claims and compensation for work injuries. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding the maximum annual rate of basic pay under title 5. The Chairperson may appoint additional staff and set their pay, exempt from certain civil service laws regarding appointments and pay rates. The Commission may procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the maximum annual rate of basic pay. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and obtain information from government agencies. They can also accept and use gifts, bequests, or devises of services or property. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, or devises of services or property, including money and proceeds from sales, which will be deposited in the Treasury for disbursement. They can also use the United States mails and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. Additionally, the Commission may contract with and compensate as provided in appropriations Acts. The Commission has the authority to contract with and compensate government and private agencies for research or surveys to carry out its duties under this Act. SEC. 8. REPORTS. The Commission must submit a status report within 1 year of initial appointments, a recommendation report within 18 months, and a follow-up report as required. The Commission must submit a follow-up report before its termination, identifying implemented recommendations and providing additional information as deemed appropriate. The Commission will terminate one year after submitting the required report. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 1995, 1996, and 1997 to carry out the Act.
